instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message:
Hello,
i am working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with waterdamage. I actually fixed this one but it came back for the second time now with no green light. I had to run wires around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and as it came back the first time i replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and it worked again. Now i replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again and that fixed the green light. But now PPBUS is missing (no short). I followed this path and came to <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>. It has 16,2-16,8V at pin 1-3 (pulsing up and down) and only aroung 7-9V at pin 5. I guess it has to do with the pulsing voltage. I checked <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> and when plugged in it beeps (pin 1 to pin 5) At pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> i can only measure 4,7V. I checked current sensing already but the resistances are fine (3Ohm and 23Ohm). Now i don´t know where to search next and what to do to prevent it from coming back...
Thanks for any help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: Well it could be anything around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Crappy soldering/dead chip/another corroded trace. No way to tell, you need to check everything and all traces, possible replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: ok ill try replacing it again and look around if anything measures not right. Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: Thank you. You were right. I replaced the ISL again (and after that again because it was shorting a dataline for the battery so the machine could not recognize the battery) and now it works. Any idea what could kill the ISL twice? I really want to prevent it from coming back...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: No idea, bad soldering, bad FETs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: While testing it died again and now i can´t get it back to live. <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is going up and down from 15.X to 16.X V so the ISL can not work right? I already replaced the ISL again (twice to be sure) and also <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> but no change. Still just a dimm green light (i can see it pulsing a little brighter and darker when <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is going up and down) and no sign of life. Is there anything i can do with this one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: The first thing to check when no green light is of course 3V42, ACOK. But with <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> fluctuating there is probably a problem with the 6259 or <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/35. Check traces to the gate of these FETs too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: i checked the traces to the gate and they beep to the isl on the other side of the board. I also exchanged <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> and the ISL again but still the same. Dimm green light but Voltage on <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> fluctuating between 14.X and 15.X V now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: I have no idea, it must be something around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, corroded trace/resistor/cap. No way I can tell you which one. This board should however work from a charged battery, check that too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: It is not working with a charged battery, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.0V from battery and the battery indicator is also not working

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: and there is no corrosion around the battery indicator and its connector

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: Battery indicator not working would suggest an issue on the data lines. They go to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and the SMC, take your pick.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: After replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> at least ten times id say time for a shot on the SMC... But the SMC can not cause <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> fluctuating right? <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> have 3,42V on both sides. Can this be when the SMD is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: Voltage on the data lines can indicate a problem, but 3.42V being there does not rule out a dead SMC. Check the SCL line with a scope, you should see pulses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: Unfortunately i don´t have a scope jet so i have to try a new SMC. Now the green light is back (pulsing a bit) and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is also there but fluctuation between 12.6 and 12.9V. But <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is still fluctuating between 15.X and 16.X V. I also noticed the fan wants to spin (actually its not moving but i can barely see it moving a little bit every time the voltages are goung up) Could the SMC kill the ISL in general/so often?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no steady green light
threads.message: SMC cannot kill ISL really, the other way around is very possible.
